ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.2_0: At that time Devadatta went to see Kokālika, Kaṭamodakatissaka, Khaṇḍadeviyā-putta, and Samuddadatta.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.3_0: “Come, let’s create a schism in the Sangha of the ascetic Gotama, a break in transmission.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.5_0: “The ascetic Gotama has great supernormal powers.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.7_0: “Well, let’s go to the ascetic Gotama and request five things:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.8_0: ‘Sir, in many ways the Buddha praises fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.9_0: Sir, there are five things that lead to fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.11_0: If the monks stayed in the wilderness for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.12_0: and whoever stays near an inhabited area would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.13_0: If they ate only almsfood for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.14_0: and whoever accepts an invitational meal would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.15_0: If they were rag-robe wearers for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.16_0: and whoever accepts robe-cloth from householders would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.17_0: If they live at the foot of a tree for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.18_0: If you do, you’ll commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.19_0: If they didn’t eat fish or meat for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.20_0: and whoever does would commit an offense.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.21_0: The ascetic Gotama won’t allow this.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.22_0: We’ll then be able to win people over with these five points.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.23_0: Kokālika said, “It might be possible to create a schism in the Sangha with these five points,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.24_0: for people have confidence in austerity.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.1_0: Devadatta and his followers then went to the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.3_0: “In many ways, Sir, you have few desires,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.5_0: And there are five things that lead to just that.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.7_0: It would be good, Sir, if the monks stayed in the wilderness for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.8_0: and whoever stays near an inhabited area would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.9_0: if they didn’t eat fish or meat for life, and whoever does would commit an offense.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.11_0: Those who wish may stay in the wilderness, and those who wish may live near an inhabited area.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.12_0: Those who wish may eat only almsfood and those who wish may accept invitational meals.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.13_0: Those who wish may wear rag-robes and those who wish may accept robes from householders.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.14_0: I have allowed a resting place at the foot of a tree for eight months of the year, as well as fish and meat which are pure in three respects:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.15_0: one hasn’t seen, heard, or suspected that the animal was specifically killed to feed a monastic.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.17_0: “The Buddha doesn’t allow the five points,” and he was glad and elated. He got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left with his followers.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.18_0: Devadatta then entered Rājagaha and won people over with the five points,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.19_0: “But we want to go to the ascetic Gotama and request five things:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.20_0: ‘Sir, in many ways the Buddha praises fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.21_0: Sir, there are five things that lead to fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.22_0: It would be good, Sir, if the monks stayed in the wilderness for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.23_0: and whoever stays near an inhabited area would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.24_0: If they ate only almsfood for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.25_0: and whoever accepts an invitational meal would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.26_0: If they were rag-robe wearers for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.27_0: and whoever accepts robe-cloth from householders would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.28_0: If they live at the foot of a tree for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.29_0: If you do, you’ll commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.30_0: If they didn’t eat fish or meat for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.31_0: and whoever does would commit an offense.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.32_0: saying, “The ascetic Gotama doesn’t agree to them,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.33_0: but we practice in accordance with them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.1_0: The foolish people there, those with little faith and confidence, said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.2_0: “These Sakyan ascetics are practicing asceticism and they live for the sake of erasing defilements.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.3_0: But the acetic Gotama lives in luxury and has chosen to live in abundance.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.4_0: But the wise people who had faith and confidence complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.6_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.7_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.9_0: After rebuking Devadatta in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.10_0: He said, “Is it true, Devadatta, that you’re pursuing schism in the Sangha, a break in transmission?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.13_0: “... Foolish man, how can you pursue schism in the Sangha?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.14_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.15_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.16.1_0: ‘If a monk pursues schism in a united Sangha or persists in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism, the monks should correct him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.17_0: “Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Sangha or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.18_0: Stay with the Sangha, for a united Sangha—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—is at ease.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.19_0: If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him give up that view.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.20_0: If he then stops, all is well.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.21_0: If he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.4_0: ...The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.6_0: those belonging to the same Buddhist sect and staying within the same monastic boundary.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.8_0: thinking, “What can be done so that these become various, separated, divided,” he searches for a faction and puts together a group.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.9_0: A legal issue conducive to schism:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.10_0: The group of eighteen on “without schism”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.18_0: the monk who is pursuing schism in the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.21_0: “Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Sangha or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.23_0: for a unanimous Sangha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, with one recitation.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.24_0: And they should correct him a second
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.25_0: And they should correct him a third time.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.26_0: If she stops, all is well.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.27_0: If he does not stop, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.28_0: If those who heard about it do not say anything, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.29_0: That monk, even if he has to be pulled into the Sangha, should be corrected like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.30_0: “Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Sangha or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.32_0: for a unanimous Sangha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, with one recitation.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.39_0: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.40_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.41_0: The monk so-and-so is pursuing schism in the united Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.42_0: And he keeps on doing it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.43_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should press him to make him stop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.45_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.46_0: The monk so-and-so is pursuing schism in the united Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.47_0: And he keeps on doing it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.48_0: The Sangha presses him to make him stop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.49_0: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him stop should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.50_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.52_0: For the third time I speak on this matter.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.53_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.54_0: The monk so-and-so is pursuing schism in the united Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.55_0: And he keeps on doing it.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.57_0: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him stop should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.58_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.59_0: The Sangha has pressed monk so-and-so to stop.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.60_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.62_0: After the motion, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.63_0: After each of the first two announcements, she commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.64_0: When the last announcement is finished, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.65_0: For one who commits the offense entailing suspension, the offense of wrong conduct and the serious offenses are annulled.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.66_0: He commits an offense entailing suspension:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.67_0: ... Therefore, too, it is called “an offense entailing suspension”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:3.1.1_0: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, but he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:3.2.8_0: The tenth rule, the training rule on schism in the Sangha, is finished.
